p.s: In his speech Boris Johnson tries to motivate his audience to act against climate change and he tries to get the responsibility toward the younger generations accrosacros to his listeners.
His speech is devideddivided into nine parts.
In the first part (l. 1-9) Boris Johnson says welcome to everybody (l. 1) and introducing them to the topic.
He welcomes them twice by using a parallelism (l. 1) to connect the following metaphor about James Bond to the beginning and Glasgow, where the climate summit takes place.
Boris Johnson compares the James Bond movies and the doomsday device (l. 3) in it to the actual situation with the climate change right now (ll. 2-8).
The Second part is a look back into the past and what happendhappened before (ll. 10-15).

This paragraph is showing the history of the fight against climate change: first the acknowledgment (l. 10), then the promises the politianspoliticians did not keep, which are critizisedcriticised by Johnson, who is making fun of them by using blah, blah, blah (l. 13), and at last the present, where they have the opportunity to do something and have to do something (ll. 14f.).
The third part (ll. 16f.) is short and is there to give hope (we can (l. 6)).
Johnson uses a anumerationenumeration (l. 16) to show what they are capable of and he is also referring back to the beginning by using again the metaphor with the doomsday device (ll. 16f.).
In the next part (ll. 18-21) he shows that the industrial countries are responsible to save the earth because they are guilty (l. 19).
In the following part (ll. 22-29) he presents his idea to integrate the economy to the plans.
To convince his audience he starts this part with a repetition of not (l. 22) to show that the governementgovernment can notcannot solve this problem alone.
At the end of this part he gives an example where the UK changed their energieenergy sources because of the private sector (ll. 28f.).
He uses this example to prove the effectivnesseffectiveness of his idea.
After that, a part (ll. 30-37) about the present people follows.
Boris Johnson notices that most people in the room are over 60 (l. 35) and is about to decide about the future of the young people outside (l. 33).
After that introduction of the problematic between the generations, Johnson looks in the next part to the younger generations (ll. 38-44).
He starts in line 37 to repeat the word children four times, he does this to let the politicians focus on the young generations and their judgementjudgment (ll. 38, 42).
At the end of this paragraph he uses the metaphor end of the story (l. 43) to express the urgency to act.
The next part (ll. 45-47) shall motivate the audience to make concrete plans, so do the parallelism and the anumerationenumeration in line 46 and 47.
In the last part (ll. 48-52) he refers back to the beginning and the James Bond metaphor (ll. 48, 50 bomb).
In line 48 he uses irony to make the audience laugh and stop the tightening.
But then he brings the tightening back by making clear thethey have to begin at least (l. 50).

In conclusion we have to say he wants the audience to feel speacialspecial by comparing them to James Bond but also wants to make them understand that they have to decide for the following generations.
